title: LRINEC Score for Necrotizing Soft Tissue Infection
description: Screens for necrotizing soft tissue infections using laboratory parameters

parameters.name: wbc
parameters.description: White Blood Cell count in cells/µL

ranges.interpretation: Low risk for necrotizing fasciitis (<50% probability). However, 10% of patients with necrotizing fasciitis still had a score <6. Clinical suspicion remains important.
Moderate risk for necrotizing fasciitis (50-75% probability). Consider urgent surgical consultation and close monitoring.
High risk for necrotizing fasciitis (>75% probability). Urgent surgical consultation and immediate operative intervention strongly recommended.

references: Wong CH, Khin LW, Heng KS, Tan KC, Low CO. The LRINEC (Laboratory Risk Indicator for Necrotizing Fasciitis) score: a tool for distinguishing necrotizing fasciitis from other soft tissue infections. Crit Care Med. 2004 Jul;32(7):1535-41. doi: 10.1097/01.ccm.0000129486.35458.7d.

Bechar J, Sepehripour S, Hardwicke J, Filobbos G. Laboratory risk indicator for necrotising fasciitis (LRINEC) score for the assessment of early necrotising fasciitis: a systematic review of the literature. Ann R Coll Surg Engl. 2017 Jun;99(5):341-346. doi: 10.1308/rcsann.2017.0053.

Fernando SM, Tran A, Cheng W, Rochwerg B, Kyeremanteng K, Seely AJE, et al. Necrotizing soft tissue infection: diagnostic accuracy of physical examination, imaging, and LRINEC score: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Ann Surg. 2019 Jan;269(1):58-65. doi: 10.1097/SLA.0000000000002774.
formula: LRINEC score = CRP points + WBC points + Hemoglobin points + Sodium points + Creatinine points + Glucose points. CRP ≥150 mg/L (4 pts), WBC >25K (2 pts), 15-25K (1 pt), Hgb <11 (2 pts), 11-13.5 (1 pt), Na <135 (2 pts), Cr >1.6 (2 pts), Glucose >180 (1 pt).
notes: Developed to distinguish necrotizing fasciitis from other soft tissue infections
Based on six laboratory parameters routinely obtained in emergency departments
Original study showed PPV of 92% and NPV of 96% for scores >6
Subsequent validation studies have shown variable performance
10% of patients with necrotizing fasciitis had scores <6 in original study
Cannot definitively rule out necrotizing fasciitis with low scores
Should be used as adjunct to clinical assessment, not replacement
High clinical suspicion should prompt surgical consultation regardless of score
Time-sensitive condition requiring urgent recognition and treatment
Not prospectively validated in original development study
Performance may vary in different patient populations (e.g., diabetics)
Clinical judgment remains paramount in diagnosis and management decisions
